Sure. Here's an example of how to generate a token in Python. 

```python 

import requests 

url = 'https://cpaas.messagecentral.com/auth/v1/authentication/token?country=IN&customerId=C- X9XX56B0380XXX&email=demo@messagecental.com&key=<BASE64_Encoded_Password>&scope=ALL' 

payload = {} 

headers = { 

  'Content-Type': 'application/json' 

} 

response = requests.request("GET", url, headers=headers, data=payload) 

print(response.text) 

``` 

In the above code, make sure to replace '<Base64_Encoded_Password>' with your actual Base64 encoded password. The response will be the authentication token that you can use for subsequent API calls. 

For more details, you can refer to the API documentation here: Token Generation

Sure! Here's an example of sending an OTP using Python:

```python
import requests

url = "https://cpaas.messagecentral.com/verification/v2/verification/send?country=IN&customerId=C-X9XX56B0380XXX&mobileNumber=99906XXX25&templateId=TEMPLATE_0009"

payload = {}

headers = {
  'authToken': '<authToken>',
  'Content-Type': 'application/json'
}

response = requests.request("POST", url, headers=headers, data=payload)

print(response.text)
```

Make sure to replace '<authToken>' with the actual authentication token received from the token generation API.

For more details, you can refer to the API documentation here: Send OTP

Certainly! Here's an example of how to validate an OTP using Python: 

```python

import requests

url = "https://cpaas.messagecentral.com/verification/v2/verification/validate?country=IN&customerId=C-X9XX56B0380XXX&mobileNumber=99906XXX25&otp=123456&verificationId=<verificationId>"

payload = {}

headers = {

  'authToken': '<authToken>',

  'Content-Type': 'application/json'

}

response = requests.request("POST", url, headers=headers, data=payload)

print(response.text)

```

Make sure to replace '<authToken>' with the actual authentication token received from the token generation API. Also, replace '<verificationId>' with the actual verification ID received in the response of the 'send' API.

For more details, you can refer to the API documentation here: Validate 

```

```

In the code, make sure to replace '<authToken>' with the actual authentication token received from the token generation API.

For more details, you can refer to the API documentation here: Verify OTP

messages.user: write the step by step process on how to send & validate otp using verify now
write the step by step process on how to send & validate otp using verify now
messages.assistant:
Step-by-Step Process: Sending and Validating OTP using 'Verify Now' 

Sending the OTP: 

Step 1: Generate an Authentication Token by calling the '/auth/token' endpoint. 

Step 2: Use the Authentication Token in the Request Header to call the '/verification/v2/verification/send' endpoint. 

Step 3: Pass the mandatory parameters: countryCode, mobileNumber, and 'flowType' as 'SMS'. 

Step 4: Receive the Response. If the Response Code is 200, the OTP has been successfully sent. 

Validating the OTP: 

Step 1: Use the Authentication Token in the Request Header to call the '/verification/v2/verification/validate' endpoint. 

Step 2: Pass the mandatory parameters: countryCode, mobileNumber, 'flowType' as 'SMS', and 'otp'. 

Step 3: Receive the Response. If the Response Code is 200, the OTP is valid. 

Note: The OTP validation is a one-time check. If the OTP is valid, the status will be 'SUCCESS'. If the OTP is invalid, the status will be 'FAIL'. 

For a more detailed understanding, please refer to the API Documentation provided in the previous response. 

 

'Documentation Link: 'Verify Now' API Documentation
